properties.name: Astroguard!
properties.description: You are a space bodyguard (aka. an Astroguard) and have been tasked with protecting the companion ship with the president of the entire galaxy, Mr. Jo "Ema" Ma. For the purposes of a fun game (definitely not a plothole im too lazy to explain away), your ship has been outfitted with an impenetrable shield and a simple fast firing turret while the companion ship has no defenses but has a radial shot as a backup weapon which takes 10 seconds to charge. On your way to the annual Intergalactic Candice Round Table, the president has come under attack, perpetrated by the evil Dr. Hamood Isapalin Drome. Protect the president at all costs!
properties.author: Graphic Mismatch Games

content.text:
[outline=green][size=50][b]HELP:[/b][/size][/outline]  


[outline=green][size=30][b]Controls:[/b][/size][/outline]
Use the WASD keys to move
Right Click to shoot
Left Click to use the companion ship's ability (radial shot). It needs 10 seconds to recharge.

[outline=green][size=30][b]Mechanics:[/b][/size][/outline]
You can ram into missles to destroy them
Your bullets hit the companion ship
Pick up health by running over it
Dont forget to use your Radial Shot. It can clear the screen of enemies.

[outline=green][size=30][b]Story:[/b][/size][/outline]
You are a space bodyguard (aka. an Astroguard) and have been tasked with protecting the companion ship with the president of the entire galaxy, Mr. Jo "Ema" Ma. For the purposes of a fun game (definitely not a plothole im too lazy to explain away), your ship has been outfitted with an impenetrable shield and a simple fast firing turret while the companion ship has no defenses but has a radial shot as a backup weapon which takes 10 seconds to charge. On your way to the annual Intergalactic Candice Round Table, the president has come under attack, perpetrated by the evil Dr. Hamood Isapalin Drome. Protect the president at all costs!

[outline=green][size=50][b]HELP:[/b][/size][/outline]  


[outline=green][size=30][b]Controls:[/b][/size][/outline]
Use the joystick (the gray circle) to move
Fire button (the button depicting a crosshair) to shoot
Special button (the button depicting a bunch of blue projectiles in a circle) to use the companion ship's ability (radial shot). It needs 10 seconds to recharge.

[outline=green][size=30][b]Mechanics:[/b][/size][/outline]
You can ram into missles to destroy them
Your bullets hit the companion ship
Pick up health by running over it
Dont forget to use your Radial Shot. It can clear the screen of enemies.

[outline=green][size=30][b]Story:[/b][/size][/outline]
You are a space bodyguard (aka. an Astroguard) and have been tasked with protecting the companion ship with the president of the entire galaxy, Mr. Jo "Ema" Ma. For the purposes of a fun game (definitely not a plothole im too lazy to explain away), your ship has been outfitted with an impenetrable shield and a simple fast firing turret while the companion ship has no defenses but has a radial shot as a backup weapon which takes 10 seconds to charge. On your way to the annual Intergalactic Candice Round Table, the president has come under attack, perpetrated by the evil Dr. Hamood Isapalin Drome. Protect the president at all costs!

[outline=green]GAME OVER[/outline]
[size=30]Mr. Jo "Ema" Ma has died (and its your fault)
But... whats this? A TIME MACHINE? Jo Ema Ma had a TIME MACHINE??
That means, you still have a chance!
The choice is yours.[/size]

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: westboy31, Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Ideal for explosions, hit/impacts, earthquake, etc.

Select one or more methods of shaking:
- Position:  Shake the X and/or Y position of the camera 
- Angle: Shake the rotation of the camera 
- Zoom: Shake the zoom level of the camera 

Control how the camera shakes:
- Amplitude: How far the camera moves during each shake
- Duration: Amount of time to shake the camera
- Time between shakes: Amount of time between each change of the movement of the camera
- Keep shaking until stopped (boolean)

Tips:
- For a single-shake effect, set the "Time between shakes" to be equal to "Duration"  (great for a hit or impact)
- To make the single-shake move in the opposite direction, use negative numbers 
- To repeat a single-shake effect in a loop, add a condition "Camera is not shaking" 
- Use a long "Time between shakes" to simulate a slow moving object (like a ship rocking back and forth)
- Make sure to "Stop shaking" before starting a new shake if it uses different parameters. 
- Use "Shake until stopped" to simulate engine vibration, earthquake, or pulsing
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: CameraShake
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Shake the camera on the specified layer using one or more methods of shaking (position, angle, zoom).

eventsFunctions.description: Shake the camera on the specified layer, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle, zoom).
eventsFunctions.name: CameraShake
eventsFunctions.sentence: Shake camera on _PARAM3_ layer for _PARAM5_ seconds. Use an amplitude of _PARAM1_px on X axis and _PARAM2_px on Y axis, angle rotation amplitude _PARAM6_ degrees, and zoom amplitude _PARAM7_ percent.  Wait _PARAM8_ seconds between shakes. Keep shaking until stopped: _PARAM9_

events.comment: Pass input parameters to global variables so that onScenePostEvents can use them
Determine if the shake should keep going until stopped
Add default values if none were provided
If duration is less than a single shake, increase duration to make 1 full shake

parameters.name: PowerX

parameters.description: Amplitude of shaking on the Y axis (pixels) (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerY

events.comment: Run once before every shake movement

events.name: Correct for drift and reset drift tracking variables

events.comment: Move to correct any drift from previous shake
Make initial shake NOT random so users can set a direction for a one-shake effect
After initial shake pick a random direction
Every "odd" shake, rotate clockwise (this includes the initial shake and can be used for a one shake effect)
Calculate camera zoom displacement, with linear decay over time
Save that initial shake has been processed
Calculate the fraction of shake that occured during this frame
Increase change for the first half of the shake (move away from original values)
Decrease change the second half of the shake (return to original position)
Save the amount of change to calculate drift
Save the amount of change to calculate drift
Save the amount of change to calculate drift
Stop shaking when the duration has been reached or if stop shaking has been requested

events.comment: Move to correct drift from previous shake

eventsFunctions.name: StopShaking
eventsFunctions.sentence: Stop shaking the camera

eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Users can interact with the multitouch joystick to specify angle and force values.  These values can be used to control other objects in the scene such as movement and rotation, such as for twin-stick shooter games.

Mulitouch buttons can be used whenever a game allows the user to press multiple locations at once.

How to use:

- Add the joystick behavior to a sprite that will be the joystick 
- Place the joystick object on the scene
- Run the "Activate joystick" action on every frame and specify the thumb object
- The joystick thumb object will automatically be created and moved

Tips:

- Use "Simulate a touch" functions to provide mouse and gamepad controls
- More than one joystick or button can be used at the same time
- Joystick and thumb objects should have all sides the same length
- Thumb object must be smaller than the joystick object

Calculate the percent of distance the thumb has moved from the center of joystick.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Tommaso "Giampiero" Bresciani
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Allows to input the classic Konami Code (*"Up, Up, Down, Down, Left, Right, Left, Right, B, A"*) into a scene for cheats and easter eggs.

To use it, simply **attach the behavior** to any object in a scene and use the Konami Code condition in the editor to trigger your desired effects with events.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Can be used to create enemies, NPCs, environmental objects, etc.

How to use:
- Add this behavior to an object
- Place spawners on the scene 
- Run the "Spawn objects" action on every frame
- Control spawning by adjusting behavior properties

Properties:
Spawn period:  Number of seconds before spawning another object.
Max quantity:  Each spawner will try to maintain this number of spawned objects
Offset X/Y:  Use to adjust where the object are spawned, relative to the origin of the spawner

Tips:
- Use "Object was just spawned" condition to trigger visual and sound effects (if desired)
- Set max quantity to "0" to never stop spawning objects
- Spawned objects are automatically linked to the spawner
- Note:  If max quantity has been reached and an instance is deleted, the spawner will wait the duration of spawn period before creating another instance.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ObjectSpawner

Check if max number of instances per spawner has been reached
This is used so that objects are not immediately spawned after deleting an instance after max instances had been reached
Check if max number of instances per spawner has been reached
Spawn an object when conditions are met
Note: Spawned objects are linked to the spawner to check their number per spawner

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Manage life points by damaging or healing the object.
Use damage cooldown to prevent further damage during the cooldown. 

Properties:
- Health
- Max Health
- Damage Cooldown (seconds)

Conditions:
- Is dead (no health points)
- Is just damaged

Actions:
- Damage the object (reduce health)
- Heal the object (increase health)
- Set current health
- Set maximum health

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Select one or more methods of shaking:
- Position: Shake the X and/or Y position of the object 
- Angle: Shake the angle (rotation) of the object 
- Scale: Shake the scale of the object (must be a sprite)

Control how the object shakes:
- Amplitude: How far the object moves during each shake
- Duration: Amount of time to shake the object
- Time between shakes: Amount of time between each movement of the object
- Keep shaking until stopped (boolean)

Tips:
- For a single-shake effect, set the "Time between shakes" to be equal to "Duration"  (great for a hit or impact)
- To make the single-shake move in the opposite direction, use negative numbers 
- To repeat a single-shake effect in a loop, add a condition "Object is not shaking" 
- Use a long "Time between shakes" to simulate a slow moving object (like a ship rocking back and forth)
- Make sure to "Stop shaking" before starting a new shake if it uses different parameters. 
- Use "Shake until stopped" to simulate engine vibration, earthquake, or pulsing

eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
The camera follows an object according to:
- a frame rate independent catch-up speed to make the scrolling from smooth to strong
- a maximum speed to do linear following or slow down the camera when teleporting the object
- a follow-free zone to avoid scrolling on small movements
- an offset to see further in one direction
- an extra delay and catch-up speed to give an impression of speed (useful for dash)
- position forecasting and delay to simulate a cameraman response time

A platformer dedicated behavior allows to switch of settings when the character is in air or on the floor. This can be used to stabilize the camera when jumping.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: SmoothCamera
eventsFunctionsExtensions.previewIconUrl: https://resources.gdevelop-app.com/assets/Icons/Line Hero Pack/Master/SVG/Computers and Hardware/Computers and Hardware_camcoder_gopro_go_pro_camera.svg
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: SmoothCamera

events.comment: Update private properties through setters to check their values and initialize state.

Delaying and forecasting can be used at the same time.
Forecasting only use the positions that are older than the one used for delaying.
The behavior uses a position history that is split in 2 arrays:
- one for delaying the position (from TimeFromStart to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay)
- one for forecasting the position (from TimeFromStart - CamearDelay to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay - ForecastHistoryDuration

At each frame, the camera must catchup the target by a given ratio (speed)
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1) - targetX) * speed

The frame rate must not impact on the catch-up speed, we don't want a speed in ratio per frame but a speed ratio per second, like this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1s) - targetX) * speed

Ok, but we still need to process each frame, we can use a exponent for this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * speed^timeDelta
cameraX(t) = targetX + (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * exp(timeDelta * ln(speed))

pow is probably more efficient than precalculated log if the speed is changed continuously but this might be rare enough.

eventsFunctions.description: Update delayed position and delayed history. This is called in doStepPreEvents.
eventsFunctions.name: UpdateDelayedPosition
eventsFunctions.sentence: Update delayed position and delayed history of _PARAM0_

events.comment: Add the previous position to have enough (2) positions to evaluate the extra delay for waiting mode.
Use the object center when no delay is asked.
Remove history entries that are too old to be useful for delaying and pass it to the history for forecasting.
Don't move the camera if there is not enough history.

Add the extra delay that could be needed to respect the speed limit in waiting mode.

speedRatio = min(speedMaxX / historySpeedX, speedMaxY / historySpeedY)
delay += min(0, timeDelta * (1 - speedRatio))
The time with delay is now between the first 2 indexes

eventsFunctions.name: AddForecastHistoryPosition
eventsFunctions.sentence: Add the time:_PARAM2_ and position: _PARAM3_; _PARAM4_ to the forecast history of _PARAM0_

events.comment:
Remove history entries that are too old to be useful.
Keep at least 2 positions because no forecast can be done with less positions.

eventsFunctions.description: Update forecasted position. This is called in doStepPreEvents.
eventsFunctions.name: UpdateForecastedPosition
eventsFunctions.sentence: Update forecasted position of _PARAM0_

events.comment:
Simple linear regression
y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX

Note than we could use only one position every N positions to reduce the process time,
but if we really need efficient process JavaScript and circular queues are a must.

VarianceX = sum((X[i] - MeanX))
VarianceY = sum((Y[i] - MeanY))
Covariance = sum((X[i] - MeanX) * (Y[i] - MeanY))

y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX
Axis permutation to avoid a ratio between 2 numbers near 0.

eventsFunctions.description: Project history ends position to have the vector on the line from linear regression. This function is only called by UpdateForecastedPosition.
eventsFunctions.name: ProjectHistoryEnds
eventsFunctions.sentence: Project history oldest: _PARAM2_;_PARAM3_ and newest position: _PARAM4_;_PARAM5_ of _PARAM0_

events.comment:
Perpendicular line:
pA = -1/a; 
pB = -pA * x + y

Intersection:
/ ProjectedY = a * ProjectedX + b
\ ProjectedY = pA * ProjectedX + b

Solution that is cleaned out from indeterminism (like 0 / 0 or infinity / infinity):
ProjectedX= (x + (y - b) * a) / (a + 1)
ProjectedY = y + (x * a - y + b) / (a + 1)

eventsFunctions.description: Return the ratio between forecast time and the duration of the history. This function is only called by UpdateForecastedPosition.

parameters: min(max(Object.X(), CameraX(Object.Layer(), 0) - CameraWidth(Object.Layer(), 0)/2 + Object.Behavior::PropertyMarginLeft()), CameraX(Object.Layer(), 0) + CameraWidth(Object.Layer(), 0)/2 - Object.Width() - Object.Behavior::PropertyMarginRight())

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Allow the object to fire bullets with customizable speed, angle and fire rate.

Cooldown: Time between shots (seconds)
Bullet Quantity: Number of bullets shot at once
Angle Variance: Each bullet trajectory will be adjusted by a random value within this range (degrees)
Firing Arc: Range of angles (in degrees) that bullets will shoot. Bullets are evenly spread within this range.
Rotate bullet: Change angle of bullet to match the direction it is travelling (enabled by default)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: FireBullet
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Allow the object to fire bullets with customizable speed, angle and fire rate.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Games with pixel art usually use pixels bigger than actual pixels of the screen. This can lead to big pixels partially overlapping each other which doesn't look good.

This extension allows to seamlessly keep big pixels aligned when the object is stopped and still beneficiate from the high resolution of the screen to have smooth movements.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: PixelPerfectMovement
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Pixel perfect platformer and top-down movements.

eventsFunctions.description: Return the speed necessary to cover a distance according to the deceleration.
eventsFunctions.name: SpeedToReach
eventsFunctions.sentence: Braking distance from an initial speed: _PARAM2_ and a deceleration: _PARAM3_ is less than _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Return the braking distance according to an initial speed and a deceleration.
eventsFunctions.name: BrakingDistance
eventsFunctions.sentence: Braking distance from an initial speed: _PARAM2_ and a deceleration: _PARAM3_ is less than _PARAM1_

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Seamlessly align big pixels using a top-down movement.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: PixelPerfectTopDownMovement

events.comment: Find how far to go to reach a pixel.

parameters: Object.Behavior::PropertyOffsetX() + Object.Behavior::PropertyPixelSize() * ceil((Object.X() + PixelPerfectMovement::BrakingDistance(Object.TopDownMovement::XVelocity(), Object.TopDownMovement::Deceleration()) - Object.Behavior::PropertyOffsetX()) / Object.Behavior::PropertyPixelSize())

Object.Behavior::PropertyOffsetX() + Object.Behavior::PropertyPixelSize() * floor((Object.X() - PixelPerfectMovement::BrakingDistance(Object.TopDownMovement::XVelocity(), Object.TopDownMovement::Deceleration()) - Object.Behavior::PropertyOffsetX()) / Object.Behavior::PropertyPixelSize())

events.comment: Move to the target as the movement behavior would do.
Find how far to go to reach a pixel.

parameters: Object.Behavior::PropertyOffsetY() + Object.Behavior::PropertyPixelSize() * ceil((Object.Y() + PixelPerfectMovement::BrakingDistance(Object.TopDownMovement::YVelocity(), Object.TopDownMovement::Deceleration()) - Object.Behavior::PropertyOffsetY()) / Object.Behavior::PropertyPixelSize())

Object.Behavior::PropertyOffsetY() + Object.Behavior::PropertyPixelSize() * floor((Object.Y() - PixelPerfectMovement::BrakingDistance(Object.TopDownMovement::YVelocity(), Object.TopDownMovement::Deceleration()) - Object.Behavior::PropertyOffsetY()) / Object.Behavior::PropertyPixelSize())

events.comment: Move to the target as the movement behavior would do.

The "separate" action can leave the object position with rounding errors.
The snaping is applied doStepPostEvent rather than at the beginning of doPreEvent because it must be done before the top-down movement is applied.

eventsFunctions.description: Snap on the grid vertically to remove rounding errors that could happen with the separate action.

eventsFunctions.sentence: Snap _PARAM0_ on the grid vertically if there is any rounding error

eventsBasedBehaviors.name: PixelPerfectPlatformerCharacter

events.comment: Find how far to go to reach a pixel.
Move to the target as the movement behavior would do.
